awd_titl_txt: Evaluating the Impacts of Cross-Curricular, Place-Based Pedagogy to  Enhance Student Success
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will inform the body of knowledge about the importance and conduct of undergraduate and graduate research experiences in recruiting and retaining underrepresented individuals into STEM studies, and preparing the next generation of STEM professionals. The connection of faculty to research and thereby the students to culturally and locally relevant research is an important step in retaining students who are more likely to pursue advanced degrees. For those students entering the workforce directly from a tribal college it is equally important that they have a well-defined skill set in mathematics, science, and technology for entry into the STEM workforce. 

Northwest Indian College (NWIC) will enhance its current degree program in Native environmental sciences to include modules that capture scientific concepts in a Native knowledge or place-based context.  The college will study the affects of this type of instruction on the academic success of American Indian students.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we worked collaboratively with knowledge holders, community members, Indigenous education experts, and tribal college faculty to explicitly design cross-curricular content that is grounded in place, relevant to multiple cultures, and contributed to the creation of a community of learners. More specifically, this project conducted an educational research study that investigated if aligning courses in cross-curricular, multi-year cases that are grounded in place, are culturally relevant, and contribute to community-building improved long-term student interest and success in the STEM field and contributed to the revitalization of Indigenous Knowledges.

Our project had the following hypothesis: 

Adopting a pedagogical approach that includes cross-curricular, multi-year cases that are culturally relevant, grounded in place, and creates a community of learners, will increase tribal college students; long-term success in the STEM field and contribute to revitalization of Indigenous Knowledges.

Overall, our study found that adopting multi-year case studies that are grounded in place and culture, contributed to student success in the STEM field within a tribal college setting.  In particular, these place-based cases fostered a community of learners through deep place-based engagement, fostered inter-generational knowledge transfer through enhanced student and community engagement, and contributed to student retention by connecting coursework across time and disciplines.  

Our goal for this study was to provide information that will assist both tribal colleges and their allies in better understanding how to best serve Indigenous student populations and the communities they represent, with STEM-based instruction for long-term, lasting success. Our study also aimed to inform teaching and learning practices for mainstream colleges and institutions that serve American Indian and Alaska Native populations.

This project was designed with the goal of improving instructional capacity excellence at NWIC as well as other TCUP Institutions and mainstream institutions that serve Indigenous students. This occurred through the creation and innovation model for teaching and learning in the STEM field. Our approach was novel because it brought together multiple educational theories of best practices including scaffolding, case study approach, place-based curriculum, and cohort learning.

Although these approaches are often employed at tribal colleges, the work to create a cross-curricular case study that spans multiple years had not yet occurred to our knowledge. In addition, efforts to test pedagogical approaches to meet course and program objectives, and increase student success while attending to broader and more fundamental goals of revitalizing Indigenous Knowledge and goals of self-determination was a novel approach.


Last Modified: 01/30/2023
Modified by: Emma S Norman
